original_data.question: A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?

options.A: Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
options.B: Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
options.C: Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
options.D: Tripple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray

model_response:
The findings described are characteristic of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound examination, which shows an elongated and thickened pylorus. The etiology is unknown. The incidence is 1:300 to 1:1000 live births, with males (especially firstborns) more commonly affected. The incidence is higher in infants born of younger mothers and lower in those born of older mothers. There is an increased incidence in infants born of mothers who received oxytocin during delivery. The diagnosis is usually made between 3 and 6 weeks of age. Projectile nonbilious vomiting is the rule. The infants usually feed vigorously between episodes of vomiting. Typically, the pyloric mass is palpated on physical examination. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound examination. The differential diagnosis includes preterm and postterm elective surgeries, duodenal atresia, annular pancreas, annular pyloric stenosis, and gastroesophageal reflux. The treatment is surgical pyloromyotomy.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Female parents, human or animal.
Record and study of past events.

Applied to a sign, symptom, or other manifestation that occurs multiple times at usually irregular intervals. The occurences are separated by an interval in which the sign, symptom, or manifestation is not present. []
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
Abnormal or excessive excitability with easily triggered anger, annoyance, or impatience.
Discarded animal and vegetable matter from a kitchen or the refuse from food preparation. (From Random House College Dictionary, 1982)
Use up completely.
A vessel with a narrow neck designed to accept a specific closure.
The event of being born.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.

A chromosome disorder associated either with an extra CHROMOSOME 21 or an effective TRISOMY for chromosome 21. Clinical manifestations include HYPOTONIA, short stature, BRACHYCEPHALY, upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthus, Brushfield spots on the iris, protruding tongue, small ears, short, broad hands, fifth finger clinodactyly, single transverse palmar crease, and moderate to severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY. Cardiac and gastrointestinal malformations, a marked increase in the incidence of LEUKEMIA, and the early onset of ALZHEIMER DISEASE are also associated with this condition. Pathologic features include the development of NEUROFIBRILLARY TANGLES in neurons and the deposition of AMYLOID BETA-PROTEIN, similar to the pathology of ALZHEIMER DISEASE. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p213)
Administration of vaccines to stimulate the host's immune response. This includes any preparation intended for active immunological prophylaxis.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Each of the upper and lower folds of SKIN which cover the EYE when closed.
Very large in expanse or scope; having great extent from one side to the other.
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
A physical examination focusing on areas of interest other than the heart.
Measures the acidity (pH) and the levels of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and bicarbonate in the blood.
A self-evaluation of health status.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
